results.title: Grierson Lecture 1999: Screen literacy and cultural morality in the digital era
results.brief_description:
A record of the 1999 Grierson Lecture by Lord David Putnam entitled, `Screen Literacy and Cultural Morality in the Digital Era’.

Includes:

Introduction by Jenifer Hooks Executive Director Cinemedia;
Introduction by The Honourable Mary Delahunty MP Minister for the Arts;
The Grierson Lecture
Closing remarks by Jenifer Hooks Executive Director Cinemedia;

results.title: Grierson
results.brief_description: An affectionate tribute to Dr. John Grierson, father of documentary film, who founded and led the British documentary film movement in the 30’s and who later established the National Film Board of Canada. Reveals the drive and dynamism of this Scottish-born pioneer who through his faith in the drama of everyday life and his concept of the “creative interpretation of reality” influenced many young filmmakers in his own country and abroad. Many of them appear here to talk about the Grierson they knew. Using photographs, newsreels, interviews and excerpts from Grierson’s films this documentary brings into focus the personality of this visionary and committed filmmaker. (Awards: Toronto)

results.title: Grief, trauma and sexual abuse: the stories of two women
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking from experience”.
Aimed at increasing awareness and consciousness of the crimes depicted, this episode from the “Speaking from experience” series looks at the experiences of Lucy and Tina. Lucy was sexually abused by her father as a young child; a situation that the remainder of her family was aware of. Tina was raped by an unknown assailant in her own home, a country property out of Melbourne. Both women speak candidly and honestly to varying degrees of detail about what happened to them, how they coped immediately afterwards and now, the impact it had on the rest of their family as well as intimate relationships, the benefits of talk therapy, the need for justice, and what has to be achieved to assist the healing process.

results.title: Grief
results.brief_description: Yonah, a taxi driver, wishes to bury his son who has committed suicide. But it is the start of the work day and there are not enough people at the funeral to form the requisite circle of mourners. We follow Yonah through the day and through the night, where after a series of encounters with a cross-section of urban Israelis, he returns by night to the grave site of his son. This subtle and exquisite Israeli film is itself a moving requiem for the relationship between a father and a son, and by extension, a lament for the contradictions and costs of the Jewish state.

results.title: Grief
results.creator_credit: Grief Productions, Ruth Charny, Yoram Mandel and Richard Glatzer
results.brief_description: This comic melodrama follows a group of maladjusted scriptwriters who work together on ‘The Love Judge’, a trashy daytime TV show set in a California divorce court. Mark is still grieving for his lover Kenny, but he’s in with a chance for a production job and is besotted with Bill who’s just broken up with his girlfriend. Leslie prefers Ben, the photocopier repair man while the boss Jo is preoccupied with the mysterious stains on her office couch. Fully of campily enjoyable scenes, the film is also genuinely touching. Glatzer delineates a complex set of relationships with assurance in this well structured, carefully nuanced film.

results.title: Gribouille = Heart of Paris
results.creator_credit: Roger Le Bon, Andre Daven and Marc Allegret
results.brief_description:
Camille Moresteau is serving on a jury in a murder trial. Moresteau takes pity on Nathalie Rougin and invites her to move in with his family for the duration of the trial. Moresteau’s son Claude takes an immediate interest in Nathalie while suspecting his father to have views on the young woman. Sensing her presence is causing tension in the family, Nathalie prepares to leave but not before she has stolen some valuables from the Moresteaus. The film was remade as ‘The Lady in question’ in 1940 by Charles Vidor.

Credits: Producers, Andre Daven, Roger Le Bon ; director, Marc Allegret ; writer, Marcel Achard, H. G. Lustig ; photography, Armand Thirard, G. Benoit, Michel Kelber ; music, Georges Auric ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner.
Cast: Raimu, Michele Morgan, Pauline Carton, Gilbert Gil, Jacqueline Pacaud, Julien Carette, Jean Worms, Bernard Blier, Jacques Baumer, Andrex.

results.title: Greystoke: The Legend of Tarzan, lord of the apes
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Hugh Hudson and Stanley S. Canter
results.brief_description: A lavish re-telling of the Tarzan legend which stays remarkably faithful to the original Edgar Rice Burroughs’ story. The film recounts the circumstances which led to the child Earl of Greystoke being raised by a family of apes until he is discovered by a Belgian explorer, who teaches him human language, and takes him back to the aristocratic Greystoke manor in Britain. There Tarzan must deal with the cruelty of human snobbery and hypocrisy. Christopher Lambert is Tarzan, Andie MacDowell is a pure-hearted Jane. Also starring Ralph Richardson, Ian Holm, and James Fox. Partly filmed on location in Cameroon.

results.title: Greyn - "Beckher"
results.brief_description:
This experimental music video was developed for Melbourne art-rock band, Greyn, with the assistance of the Australian Council for the Arts. A non-commercial film, it breaks down the generic film conventions of commercial music video production by not promoting the band as sexy, as rock gods, or as exceptional musicians, but by telling the story of inner balance.
The two performers, Sangeetha Jane and Daimon Barry, move through an experimental yoga/dance sequence that sees them grow and evolve over the course of a hauntingly beautiful track entitled “Beckher”.
(No title or credits)

results.title: Greyfriars Bobby: the true story of a dog
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Productions and Don Chaffey
results.brief_description: Based on the children’s book by Eleanor Atkinson, this delightful movie tells the story of a lovable and faithful terrier named Bobby. Bobby is owned by the family at Cauldbrae Farm, but he chooses his own master in “Old Jock”(Alex Mackenzie), caretaker at the farm. When Jock dies, Bobby remains steadfast in his refusal to leave his master’s gravesite at the estate where he worked. The new caretaker of the farm, James Brown (Donald Crisp), is not keen about having Bobby forced on him but the dog manages to work his way into his heart. Set against the picturesque Scottish countryside this film also stars Laurence Naismith and Kay Walsh and is a remake of “A Challenge to Lassie”.

results.brief_description: A unique six part travel and adventure series featuring the remarkable stories of six ordinary ‘older people’ making extraordinary journeys to far flung parts of the globe.
